channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Families separated by Israel’s war in Gaza fear they will never reunite
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
item.description: In the early days of the conflict, parents, husbands and wives made snap decisions about where to run. Now, some worry their separation could be permanent.

item.title: NATO says North Korean troops already deployed to Russia’s Kursk region
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Francesca Ebel
item.description: Such a deployment could put North Korean troops in direct combat with Ukrainian forces, and it could help Russia retake more of its Kursk region.

item.title: Live Briefing: IDF withdraws from northern Gaza’s last operational hospital; Cease-fire talks resume in Doha
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Jennifer Hassan, Abbie Cheeseman, Lior Soroka, Sammy Westfall
item.description: Israeli troops pulled back from Kamal Adwan Hospital after a days-long raid, the IDF said. Gaza cease-fire talks are ongoing in Doha, a person briefed on them said.

item.title: Opposition protests as pro-Russia party in Georgia takes strong election lead
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon, Mary Ilyushina
item.description: The Georgian Dream party’s founder has vowed to ban opposition parties and take the country in a pro-Russian election. Observers allege fraud in the election.

item.title: IDF withdraws from Kamal Adwan Hospital after days-long raid
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan

item.title: Nearly 1,000 people killed in Israel’s northern Gaza siege, official says
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Hajar Harb

item.title: Analysis: U.S. election winner will face turmoil in the Middle East
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor

item.title: In a warming world, English sparkling wine challenges French champagne
item.dc:creator: William Booth
item.description: Climate change has been hard for vineyards, but also made it possible to grow the grapes that make sparkling wine in southern England.

item.title: How Soviet farm planning gave Ukrainian troops vital battlefield real estate
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton, Serhii Korolchuk
item.description: On the Ukrainian steppe, where it is nearly impossible to hide from drone surveillance, windbreaks are fought over by Russian and Ukrainian troops.

item.title: As ties with the U.S. worsen, China asks: Who’s the new Kissinger?
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd, Katrina Northrop
item.description: Influential voices in China are openly discussing who could act as a trusted bridge between Beijing and Washington, regardless of who wins the presidency.

item.title: The world beyond the election: Middle East in turmoil
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: Whoever takes office in January will face a region being reshaped by an emboldened Israel and the rivalry between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Japan’s long-ruling party loses majority in stunning election defeat
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Julia Mio Inuma
item.description: The Liberal Democratic Party, which has been in power almost continuously since 1955, failed to secure an absolute majority in the lower house elections.

item.title: Israel met ‘all its objectives’ in strike; Iran vows response
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho, Annabelle Timsit, Kelsey Baker, Alon rom
item.description: “We have severely struck [Iran’s] defense capabilities and its ability to produce missiles,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said.

item.title: Storm toll rises in Philippines as country reels from landslides, flooding
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Almost 130 are dead or missing in the Philippines, the AP reported, as Tropical Storm Trami hit Vietnam but threatened to make a U-turn.

item.title: Truck ramming near Tel Aviv leaves 2 dead including driver, more than 30 injured
item.dc:creator: Heidi Levine, Annabelle Timsit, Kelsey Baker

item.title: Europe’s pledge to Ukraine tested by Trump, politics, public fatigue
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis
item.description: European leaders promise to back Ukraine for “as long as it takes,” but they face public fatigue, a weakened political center and a possible Trump comeback.

item.title: Russian economy overheating, but still powering the war against Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon
item.description: Putin’s massive spending on the war is overheating the economy, but he has the resources to keep doing it.

item.title: Iran shrugs off Israeli strikes, but says little about attack’s targets
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Jarrett Ley

item.title: Israel says it limited attack on Iran, hoping to ease tensions for now
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, Loveday Morris

item.title: Iran shrugs off Israeli strikes, but says little about attack’s targets
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Jarrett Ley
item.description: Soon after Israel’s attack, which it said hit 20 military targets and that lasted several hours, life in Iran appeared to return to normal.

item.title: Israel says it limited attack on Iran, hoping to ease tensions for now
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, Loveday Morris
item.description: Tehran was quick to downplay the damage inflicted by the Israeli strikes, although officials said at least four soldiers were killed.

item.title: Vatican meeting ends and hope fades for more change under Francis
item.dc:creator: Stefano Pitrelli, Anthony Faiola
item.description: The pope’s “Synod on Synodality” ended Saturday without progress on female deacons, married priests or LGBTQ+ outreach.

item.title: Georgia’s Moscow-leaning ruling party leads in preliminary election results
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: The Georgian Dream party said it would keep the country out of war. Opposition liberals say it is dragging the country into Russia’s orbit.

item.title: Israel strikes military targets in Iran, IDF says; Tehran describes ‘limited damage’
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Klimentov, Steve Hendrix, Missy Ryan, Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Frances Vinall, Adela Suliman, Vivian Ho, Amanda Coletta, Kelsey Baker
item.description: The Israel Defense Forces said the strikes against Iranian military targets had concluded. Iran says the damage was limited.

item.title: Strikes kill four soldiers and damage radar systems, Iranian authorities say
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman, Suzan Haidamous, Loveday Morris

item.title: President Joe Biden said Saturday that he hopes this week’s Israeli strikes in Iran are “the...
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Baker

item.title: Middle Eastern states condemn strike as U.K. and France urge de-escalation
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall, Adela Suliman, Amanda Coletta
